storyInfo: A documentarian with terminal Oripathy takes up his camera and heads for a land on which he has never set foot before.

attributes.text: Infection Diary:
Went to the hospital today. Finally got closure. It's better to know that there are rocks in my body than worry about whether they're there or not.
I've been a hospital regular since I was little. Maybe that's why I didn't feel much when the doctor gave his prognosis.
What's the meaning of life? It's a question that countless films and books have explored, and a question that means nothing to me anymore.
In the days I have left, I want to make something that truly belongs to me.
I've often wondered if our vision has been limited by the environment we can see, and the land portrayed on the television screen, without us realizing it.
We've gotten used to the sight of imposing skyscrapers and nights illuminated by neon glow, but we've forgotten how the vast nomadic cities are only a small part of this great land.
How small is man in all this?
My farewell will be a documentary.
I will leave familiar waters and go as far as I can, to see sights I've never seen before. Who lives in the furthest corners of the world, and what kind of lives do they lead?
Filming a documentary by myself won't be easy. The thought of carrying so much equipment across such distances is daunting enough on its own.
But what have I got to lose? Maybe I get an Oripathy attack halfway, and everything's over right then and there.
My time is better spent thinking of a title for the work.

attributes.content: Three hundred thirty-seven letters and twenty-five packages, correct?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Correct, but... are you sure you can carry all that?
attributes.name: Post Office Worker

attributes.content: Sure. I'm used to it.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Two week trip, with a sidetrack to a town in the west for an urgent delivery.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Things are always busy at the start of a new year. Sorry about the workload.
attributes.name: Post Office Worker

attributes.content: Don't worry, it comes with the territory.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Oh, and...
attributes.name: Post Office Worker

attributes.content: Yeah? Go on.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Well, I bought my family some new clothes and nutriments for the new year. I was hoping you might have the time, but...
attributes.name: Post Office Worker

attributes.content: Just hand over the goods.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Oh, thank you so much, boss.
attributes.name: Post Office Worker

attributes.content: Oh, cut it out, I'm not your boss. You're older than me, aren't you?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Mmph!
attributes.name: Post Office Worker

attributes.content: Er... how many pieces is it?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: That's why I wasn't sure I should say...
attributes.name: Post Office Worker

attributes.content: I mean, if it's too much...
attributes.name: Post Office Worker

attributes.content: Just load them up. A few pieces more or less won't make a difference.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Thanks!
attributes.name: Post Office Worker

attributes.content: Oh, and send my love to my folks, if you see them. Tell them I'll definitely be back for the next new year.
attributes.name: Post Office Worker

attributes.content: Gotcha.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I'd better get going.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Er... excuse me? Can I have a moment of your time?
Who? Me?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Yes!
Are you the local Messenger?
Guess so... I handle all the letters and parcels in these mountains.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: And who might you be?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Oh, I'm a director. I'm filming a documentary about this region.
Can I travel with you for a while? And, with your permission, film you as well...?
I-I'm telling the truth!
It's just that I lost my ID on my way here from the last village, and I don't have anything else on me to prove my identity.
Look! All I have in my bag is filming equipment.
Did you say 'documentary?'
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Well, a documentary is...
I know what a documentary is. But why me?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I want to record the lives of the people who live in these mountains, but I don't know the area. As a Messenger, I'm sure you...
Alright, I get it.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I'll stay out of your way, I promise!
I'm afraid I can't compensate you, but I would be happy to put your name at the top of the credits...
That's not what I'm worried about.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Well... alright...
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I'm not sure what you're trying to film...
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: But as long as you can keep up...
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.text: I left a simple farewell letter to my parents and a few close friends, asking them to forgive me for leaving without saying goodbye. I've never been good with words, and time is short.
My parents always wanted to keep me sheltered. I understand their worries, but I also have my reasons.
I hope they'll understand when they watch the film.
I felt joy and excitement as I never had before when, for the first time, my feet touched earth that was real, not man-made.
I felt as though I saw more in the span of a few months than I had in all the decades prior.

I saw starry skies clear and bright, saw the soil turned over by Catastrophe, saw Chidao builders busy at work in the barrenlands, saw Catastrophe Messengers tirelessly traveling from one place to another.

I traversed uninhabited deserts, crossed silent glaciers, and passed by peaceful, verdant villages. They invited me to stay for the Yanese New Year's Eve and to share in a cup of mijiu that they made themselves.
In fact, I've had enough of writing stories that cater to the audience, all for a few more tickets sold at the box office, a few guffaws or tears, then forgotten forever.
Art is not something to be consumed once and thrown away. It should have some sort of lasting meaning, some sort of weight.
Why not capture the authentic lives of the people, rather than try to make faux imitations of them?
Every frame my camera captures is meaningful.
I want to see with my own eyes distant lands and the people who live there.
Now, in my last days, I feel more alive than ever.
Ironically, it's only made me more afraid of the end.

attributes.content: Narration:
The Messenger's day begins before sunrise, at the hour when starlight begins to give way to dawn.
In remote regions like this, the delivery of parcels, letters, even simple messages, requires no ordinary effort.
Messengers embark on long journeys into the wilds, facing a multitude of risks and challenges. This Messenger, for instance, walks a dozen li every day—
Dozens of li.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: A dozen li won't even get me over a single peak.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Sorry, my mistake. I'll redo the narration...
You still good? Need help with your backpack?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: N-No...
I-I can handle it...
We only reached one village today. That's a lot slower than normal.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I'm sorry... I'll do my best to keep up.
Just take it easy.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Let's take a break. It would only be more trouble if you collapsed. You're not exactly an athlete, by the looks of it.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Have some water.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: And tie this bandage around your ankle, or by tomorrow it'll be swollen, and you can't even walk.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: T-Thank you...
Sorry about this... I didn't mean to be a burden.
Hah. Not like I ever expected a city boy to keep up with me.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: What exactly have you been filming, anyway?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Just the scenes and people along the way...
I've seen movies too, seen the glamorous scenes, handsome actors, and beautiful actresses...
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Is there a reason you're filming bare mountains like these?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Of course there is!
True beauty lies in that which is authentic. Glamorous, whitewashed scenes are no more than a deception.
There's meaning in filming that which no one has ever seen and that which has become lost to the passage of time, so that more people can see them.
Hm...
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Since we're taking a break, may I interview you?
Inter... view?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Just asking some questions. You don't have to answer, if you don't want to.
I guess... do I talk into the camera?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Have you always lived in these mountains?
I left for a few years to go to school, and came back after graduating.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Could you talk about this place from your own perspective?
Er... talk about it?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: It's just what you're looking at... ordinary mountains, far away from civilization. Not a lot of people here, and even fewer visitors.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Nothing's really changed as far as I can remember... other than the building of the Chidao.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: How do the people here make a living?
Most years, we grow enough to feed ourselves, and trade any surplus we have for other things we need.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: The climate may be dry, but it's just right for certain fruits.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: A while back, I was thinking whether there was a way to sell the fruit grown in the village to the cities.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: But the cost of transportation was too high, so nothing came of it.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: A lot of the villages look pretty empty.
People had been moving to the nomadic cities for years. The young people went first. Now, even the children and elderly are following.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Not much has changed here, but the cities expand quickly. There are more jobs there.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I'm the only one left in the village where I grew up.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: They went to the cities? Why did you stay here?
I'm Infected, after all.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Maybe I could have gone if I really wanted to, but I took a look at myself in the mirror, and traversing these mountains is what I do best.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Rather than start from scratch in an unfamiliar place, I would rather do what I can, especially if this helps other people.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Plus, who would deliver the mail if I left?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Isn't it tough?
Have you ever thought it was unfair?
Tough?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Is there anything that isn't tough? I'm more comfortable doing what I'm good at, what I'm familiar with.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: As far as fair or unfair... who's to judge that sort of stuff? I would rather just do my job.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Or did you think that life outside the cities was hell?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Things might be monotonous here, but it's not so bad that we have to beg for sympathy.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: There's nothing wrong with working hard and making a simple, grounded living.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I guess you're right...
But how could there be change, if things continue like this?
Change?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Things are changing every day.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Today's house is a little more solid than yesterday, and today's crops grow a little taller.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: That's not the kind of change I'm talking about!
I'm talking about change on a larger scale, on a structural level...
People shouldn't be limited by what they were born into... they should have equal access to resources and opportunities no matter where they live.
Sure, that's a nice thought to have... but you've got to start with solid, hard work, after all.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Let's give this a rest, we've gone way off topic.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Alright, we can about something else. What about yourself?
Myself? What is there to talk about it?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: As a Messenger, what sort of regrets do you have? What are your hopes of the future? What's been the most unforgettable thing in your career?
Unforgettable thing...?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I'll tell you, but only if you turn off the camera.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Sure!
There was one time when I was hurrying through the mountains overnight to make an urgent delivery.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: It was raining, and the dirt on the slopes started to come lose. Rocks came rolling down the slope...
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Was your infection—
No, no.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I saw a big rock that was about to fall onto the parcels. I don't know what I was thinking in the heat of the moment, so I tried to knock it away with my horns...
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: That's how I broke my left horn.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Pffft––
Are you laughing?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: S-Sorry, I didn't mean to—
Whatever. Still better than the long look on your face you've been having.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I find it funny too. I still carry the broken horn with me, to remind myself not to rush on rainy nights.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: And maybe I could find a doctor to put it back, if I get the chance.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I've done a lot of dumb things and seen a lot of interesting sights on my deliveries.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: But I'm usually by myself, and there's no one to tell my stories to.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Well, here's your chance. Any other stories you care to tell?
And have you ever thought that you're not really by yourself when you're delivering?

attributes.text: 'When you look back at your life, what do you feel?'
I've asked many people the same question, and the answers are often similar.
All the ups and downs of life, summarized in a few words.
The Messenger talked about life in the mountains, her lost home, her infection, as though she was talking about going out for a walk after dinner.
But what kind of pain, suffering and frustrations lie behind her dispassionate words? What helplessness does she feel, of which even she is not aware?
We are all equally helpless, before the great maw of 'reality'.
How would I answer the question myself?
What more can I record with my camera, and what more can I do, before the end comes?
What would I leave behind?

attributes.content: We'll camp in this forest today.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Do you always camp outside like this when you're out delivering?
I spend the night in villages whenever I can, but sometimes they're too far away to make it before sundown.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Bad luck to have to camp outside on your first trip to the mountains.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: But I'm surprised you've made it this far. I thought you would give up a long time ago.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Haha... I might have done that in the past, but there are reasons why I have to keep going this time.
The job of a Messenger is harder than I thought.
You get used to it, after a while.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I guess doing this once is plenty for you.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: But there are many who will remained trapped here, far away from civilization, after I'm gone...
I'm hoping there will come a day when people don't have to live like this anymore.
Like this?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Yes. Maybe bringing attention to how things are here can help bring about change.
I don't understand why you keep talking about changing this place.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Like a few words would change anything.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: All I can do is raise awareness.
But it's worth trying, so we can change this backwater...
Enough.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I—
I don't get what you're going for with this so-called documentary.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: You said you wanted to learn about the people's lives, but what have you actually learned?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: You don't know how the people farm, what they do as the seasons change, how they drill wells in the wild. You don't even know the price of a pound of grain.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: You don't know anything.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I may not know much, but I've seen things here with my own eyes.
Didn't you say you wanted to see change?
Yes, life here is hard, much poorer than in the cities.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: But the people here do their best to make a living in their own way.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: For someone like you who doesn't actually know the people here, who are you to judge our lives and look down on us? What gives you the right to talk about 'change?'
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: You've got a lot of grand talk about 'compassion,' but in the end, you're just looking down on us, pitying us.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: You don't need me to guide you, and I'm not gonna help you with your documentary anymore. Zai jian.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Sorry, that's not what I meant!
Wait—
Leave me alone!
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I've done what I could to fix the camera. Check it out. Is the data in there still good?
attributes.name: Click

attributes.content: Yes, thanks.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: It's the newest model, released last year. I wanted one too, but couldn't bring myself to spend half-a-year's income.
attributes.name: Click

attributes.content: How did it get so damaged, though? Did its old owner throw it or something?
attributes.name: Click

attributes.content: No, nothing like that...
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: So what's in it?
attributes.name: Click

attributes.content: Some scenery... I guess...
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: Your test results are in, Wind Chimes.
attributes.name: Mulberry

attributes.content: Thanks.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: I can give you the room, if you want to look at them now—
attributes.name: Mulberry

attributes.content: Hey, these aren't too bad. You had me worried there for a second.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: I'm not exactly a doctor, but those aren't great numbers...
attributes.name: Mulberry

attributes.content: Remember to wear proper protective equipment on your deliveries.
attributes.name: Mulberry

attributes.content: Will do, thanks.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: I appreciate you telling me about Rhodes Island... and about the village.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: Thank you for everything.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: I thought it was just a natural disaster when I went there... I never could've imagined there was such a story behind it.
attributes.name: Mulberry

attributes.content: I just wonder, if I had showed up a little earlier...
attributes.name: Mulberry

attributes.content: Don't say that. No point in dwelling on it.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: Everyone is helpless in the face of these things.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: The boy who died in the mudslide...
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: I'm sorry... I contacted Chun-qian HQ asked for recent reports of missing persons, we haven't had a match yet.
attributes.name: Mulberry

attributes.content: I see...
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: There's just so little information. No name, no ID, no idea where he came from.
attributes.name: Mulberry

attributes.content: Do you have any more information about the video? Maybe it could provide a clue.
attributes.name: Mulberry

attributes.content: He... he was Infected.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: Other than that...
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: Well, that doesn't really...
attributes.name: Mulberry

attributes.content: Don't worry, I'll keep looking.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: I'm sure he left something behind on his journey.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.text: You came so far and met so many people. Someone like you must have left some trace.
Somewhere, amongst all the sights you saw, there will be word about you.

attributes.content: Oh, by the way, I'm going to Moushan one of these days.
attributes.name: Mulberry

attributes.content: I want to check on the rebuilding of the disaster fortifications there.
attributes.name: Mulberry

attributes.content: Sure, let's go together.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: Hey! Any letters for me?
attributes.name: Noisy Crowd

attributes.content: Stop pushing! I see my letter!
attributes.name: Noisy Crowd

attributes.content: No need to rush, folks. Get in line, one at a time...
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: See there, Wang? Letter for you! Now stop crying.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Good news about your son's university application, Zhang? I see you grinning from ear to ear. Congrats.
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: I've never seen faces like that.
People gather around the Messenger, waiting for news carried on a single piece of paper, news from their loved ones beyond the mountains.
On everyone's faces is sincere expectation, sincere emotion. I share in their feelings through the camera lens.
Their expectations are humble, but they are not lacking in emotions.
Perhaps the lives of people are not so different after all. All the ups and downs of life, summarized in a few words.
Life and death, joy and sorrow, meeting and parting.
What are you filming?
attributes.name: Messenger

attributes.content: Two months have passed, and the village looks very different.
It is the idle season for farming, but the villagers are as busy as ever. A few more wells have popped up, and the villagers gather around the fields to study newly-installed irrigation equipment.
A drop of dew falls on her face. She looks up to see that a few flowers have bloomed on the old pagoda tree at the village entrance, swaying with the warm summer breeze.
She remembers something that someone said to her once.

attributes.text: 'When you hurry through the night, do you forget to look up at the stars above or down to see the flowers blooming in the cracks of the path?'

attributes.content: Wind Chimes picks up the camera.
Ready? I'm gonna press it!
attributes.name: Cheerful Child

attributes.content: Are you sure it won't blow up?
attributes.name: Hesitant Child

attributes.content: Three, two—
attributes.name: Cheerful Child

attributes.content: It's moving!
attributes.name: Cheerful Child

attributes.content: What's this?
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: A tractor we made out of tools abandoned by the Chidao builders! We learned how to do it from the books!
attributes.name: Cheerful Child

attributes.content: Quiet down! They'll yell at us if they find out.
attributes.name: Hesitant Child

attributes.content: What did you build it for?
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: To go to Lungmen!
attributes.name: Cheerful Child

attributes.content: We've always wanted to see the big city.
attributes.name: Cheerful Child

attributes.content: I hear there are huge shopping malls there, giant movie theaters, and pianos as big as the Elder's backyard!
attributes.name: Cheerful Child

attributes.content: What's the point? We'll still have to come back...
attributes.name: Hesitant Child

attributes.content: So much going on in the village, drilling new wells, fixing the pipes, moving the Yishan Temple...
attributes.name: Hesitant Child

attributes.content: So many things to do since the Elder left, and no one knows where to start...
attributes.name: Hesitant Child

attributes.content: You need to look higher and further! We'll be able to do what we want once we grow up.
attributes.name: Cheerful Child

attributes.content: You've been to the cities, right, lady Messenger?
attributes.name: Cheerful Child

attributes.content: Hm...
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: It's good to see places you've never been before.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: Let me take a photo for you.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: Carry the photo with you, and you'll always be able to remember what home looks like, even when you're far away.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: Let's do it! Commemoration for our big adventure!
attributes.name: Cheerful Child

attributes.content: Over here, we'll sit on the tractor.
attributes.name: Cheerful Child

attributes.content: Look at the camera and smile.
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.content: Three, two—
attributes.name: Wind Chimes

attributes.text: If your last wish is to finish the journey and the documentary, then I'll do all I can to help you fulfill it.
Maybe I finally understand why you do this. There are sights that I've never noticed, even in familiar places.
Villages disappear and people leave, but they leave behind traces that can be captured.
Thank you for telling me your stories and listening to mine.
I'm sorry I didn't get to know you better.

attributes.content: The less-than-amicable parting with the interviewee is yet another unexpected challenge. But I have to keep going.
The argument made me reflect and realize that one cannot rely on books alone to learn about life. My understanding of 'hardship' remains shallow.
Life is a journey with predetermined starting and ending points, a journey that one stumbles through, searching for a path.
The paths may differ, but we all fight against the tides of fate and struggle against the monsters of reality for the sake of the scenery we cling to.
These struggles are a source of hardship, yet they are also noble.
I may have had misfortune, but never misery. This realization has set my mind at ease.
I shall go forward and keep walking.
I should apologize to the Messenger, if I see her.
Maybe I'd better do it now.
Hello, Miss Messenger.
I don't have a pen or paper with me, so all I can do is record my apology this way.
I'm sorry for offending you.
I wanted to explain that I didn't mean to look down on anyone; I just wanted to do what I can, to do something meaningful, just like you.
I really respect your commitment and courage.
I haven't been able to live 'authentically' like you do, but thanks to you, I'm a little closer to 'authentic'.
Once again, I apologize for offending you, and for my lack of understanding.
I hope you will see this apology, informal as it is, someday.
Yours sincerely—
Oof!
Hey! Watch where you're going!
attributes.name: Annoyed Youth

attributes.content: You said this machine keeps anything you see? Forever?
attributes.name: Curious Youth

attributes.content: Yes, it permanently records anything it captures.
Can you record me too?
attributes.name: Curious Youth

attributes.content: Er, sure...
What do you want to say?
My name is Fang Xiaoshi! I'm going to be the greatest hero in all the lands!
attributes.name: Proud Youth

attributes.content: Remember the name! You'll hear it again soon.
attributes.name: Proud Youth

attributes.content: Alright, I will.
Anyway, I've gotta run. There's a great demon after me...
attributes.name: Proud Youth

attributes.content: I'm off! Zai jian!
attributes.name: Proud Youth

attributes.content: Alright.
Zai jian.
